title: 1225-D
statement: D. Power Productstime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test512 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given $$$n$$$ positive integers $$$a_1, \\ldots, a_n$$$, and an integer $$$k \\geq 2$$$. Count the number of pairs $$$i, j$$$ such that $$$1 \\leq i < j \\leq n$$$, and there exists an integer $$$x$$$ such that $$$a_i \\cdot a_j = x^k$$$.InputThe first line contains two integers $$$n$$$ and $$$k$$$ ($$$2 \\leq n \\leq 10^5$$$, $$$2 \\leq k \\leq 100$$$).The second line contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, \\ldots, a_n$$$ ($$$1 \\leq a_i \\leq 10^5$$$).OutputPrint a single integer — the number of suitable pairs.ExampleInput6 3 1 3 9 8 24 1Output5NoteIn the sample case, the suitable pairs are:$$$a_1 \\cdot a_4 = 8 = 2^3$$$;$$$a_1 \\cdot a_6 = 1 = 1^3$$$;$$$a_2 \\cdot a_3 = 27 = 3^3$$$;$$$a_3 \\cdot a_5 = 216 = 6^3$$$;$$$a_4 \\cdot a_6 = 8 = 2^3$$$.
